columns.text: In this problem, we will do an analysis on the different break-even points of the project. There are three different break-even points, accounting, cash, and financial.

**a.** Going back to the definition of accounting break-even, we can recall that this is the point where in the business generates exactly zero profits. 

IRR or the internal rate of return is the computation of the rate of return without considering external factors. In the case of this situation, the IRR is **zero** since we are at accounting break even which means that the initial investment is still being recovered so there is no return yet.

The payback period refers to the amount of time it takes to recover the initial investment or to reach break even. In this case, the payback period is **N years** since this is the amount of time that the investment is recovered to break even.

Finally, the NPV, or the net present value, basically refers to the difference of the cash outflow and inflow. It generally describes the profitability of the project. In the case of this project at accounting break-even point, we can conclude that it is not yet profitable. Thus, the NPV value should be **negative** as we are still recovering the initial investment.

**b.** At cash break-even, the cashflow of the company is exactly zero. 

Going back to the definition of IRR, we know that since the cash flow is exactly zero, then the IRR is negative. Since there is no cash flow, then that means there is no progress towards getting your return of investment, thus an IRR of $-100\%$ is given.

Again, since there is no cashflow and the rate of return is highly negative, then the payback period is also highly negative.

Since the NPV is basically the summation of the cashflow relative to the discount rate, then the value of NPV at cash break-even is equal to the $-\$I$ which is the initial cost of the project.

**c.** The financial break-even point refers to the point in which the NPV is zero. 

In this case, the IRR is the same as the expected rate of return which is $R\%$ in this case.

For the payback period, this can be solved accordingly but generally speaking, it should be less than $N$ which is the life span of the project.

For the NPV, as stated in the definition, this is equal to zero.
